title: How to say this sentence, 'Tthe thought of being in a constant learning situation and being in a university environment where I have access to unlimited learning opportunities convince me to continue my education further.' - Quora

response.answer_text: This sentence is kind of a ‘run - on’ sentence (meaning you should break it into two or more shorter sentences because it is too long), but if you wanted to keep the sentence in this form there is only one grammatical error that I found. ‘The thought of being in a constant learning situation and being in a university environment where I have access to unlimited learning opportunities’ is the full subject here. This sentence takes third person singular ‘it.’ You must conjugate the verb ‘to convince’ with third person singular in simple present, which is ‘convinces.’ Another option, which was shown in a previous answer by Joseph, is to put the verb ‘to convince’ into the simple past as ‘convinced.’ You could even play with the tense and make it a continuous statement like ‘is convincing me to continue my education further.’ To add, you could use present perfect as well, ‘has convinced me to continue my education further.’ Any of these tenses could work in this sentence; just remember to conjugate the verb in third person singular! I hope that helps.

It’s repetitive. Maybe say something like: A university environment gives students access to broad learning potential. Therefore, I would further my education because ___________________________. Otherwise. The sentence has no special message other than stating that access to a university stimulates education. THE READER needs to know why the university is such a fantastic environment for your learning potential. (Talk about your interests in the frame of what you’ve already said.) Give the idea purpose if you’re going to use it.
